name: qsv-datefmt
description: Formats recognized date fields (19 formats recognized) to a specified date format using strftime date format specifiers.

args.name: column
args.description: The column/s to apply the date formats to. Note that the <column> argument supports multiple columns. See 'qsv select --help' for the format details.

args.name: input
args.description: The input file to read from. If not specified, reads from stdin.

options.description: The number of rows per batch to load into memory, before running in parallel. Automatically determined for CSV files with more than 50000 rows. Set to 0 to load all rows in one batch. Set to 1 to force batch optimization even for files with less than 50000 rows. [default: 50000]
The field delimiter for reading CSV data. Must be a single character. (default: ,)
The number of jobs to run in parallel. When not set, the number of jobs is set to the number of CPUs detected.
If a formatted date ends with "T00:00:00+00:00", keep the time instead of removing it.
Put the transformed values in a new column instead.
When set, the first row will not be interpreted as headers.
Write output to <file> instead of stdout.
Prefer to parse dates in dmy format. Otherwise, use mdy format.
Show progress bars. Not valid for stdin.
New name for the transformed column.
The resolution to use when parsing Unix timestamps. Valid values are "sec", "milli", "micro", "nano". [default: sec]
Shortcut for --input-tz and --output-tz set to UTC.
Shortcut for --output-tz set to UTC and --formatstr set to "%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ".
